Also, note that the Big bang shares one commn point of start for all matter in existence today.
This in turn means that the matter that is the farthest away from that point also moved the fastest,
and is moving very fast still.
If the age of universe is x years, and the distance in ly nears this x value, it also
means that the velocity nears the lightspeed.
After all if you are in GN-z11, you have been travelling that distance for at best roughly 14 billion years.
Now given the distance there is 14 billion LY which have been travelled during this period,
which then equates into a speed differential of roughly the speed of light.
But like said, the speed differential may exceed the speed of light by at most a factor of two.
So, that as a another given the speed was between lightspeed and half lightspeed,
dependant on the average speed over the distance and tim to reach us.
Since both speeds together must add up to the total speed differential, from a vector
counter vector perspective, then whatever the speed we have along the vector opposite
to the direction of the GN-z11 galaxy must be subtracted from the speed
along the vector towards the GN-z11 galaxy as it's speed.
So, technically, the maximum distance between celestial objects is limited to
twice the speed of light over the duration of the current existence of the Unverse's filler.
And this then is only possible for objects that would be moving apart at a perfect 180 degree
angle from each other since the Big Bang at lightspeed.
Then there's the age of the current Universe filler, which may be older, which would
then also diminsh the speed required over time, lowering the speed calculated for GN-z11.

1:18 Well actually not true, speed differentals can reach twice the speed of light.
If you have one laser pointing one way and another directly in the opposing direction,
technically the tips of these photon beams can move away from each other
at twice the speed of light, despite both being bound by the speed of light.
Now if a moving object is moving at higher fraction of light, and another
is moving in the opposite direction, they can actually appear to be moving
faster than the speed of light, when it comes to sum of speed differentials.
This in and by itself does not mean that either is moving at above lightspeed.

Hubble detects object moving away from us with a speed faster than light. OK.
Does that mean, the objects have to travel faster than the speed of light?
If one person moves away from a point with a certain speed, and another moves away from that same point with the same speed, in the opposite direction, than the two persons are moving away from eachother with twice the speed they are moving away from that particular point. Their relative speed (relative as in related to eachother) is twice the speed, they actually move (their absolute speed).

Hence, if our galaxy moves away from the center of our universe (where the Big Bang took place) with 0,6 times the speed of light, and another galaxy is moving away from that point with the same speed, but in the opposite direction, then yes, that galaxy would be moving away from us with a relative speed greater than the speed of light, without any of the galaxies travelling faster than the speed of light in absolute terms.

NO!...the objects, mainly galaxies and large star clusters, themselves are not traveling faster than "light speed", no; it is their relative speed speeding away from Earth, as Earth and the Milkyway Galaxy is itself speeding away from them, combined that produces a speed greater than light speed: for example, say you can run max out at 10 miles and hour, I can also run max out at 10 miles an hour...neither of us can individually run faster than 10 MPH; however, our combined speed running away from each other would be 20 MPH: your 10 going away from me plus my 10 going away from you equals a total of 20 MPH.  That's called separation speed, not the actual speed of  an object (relative to the space it is traveling through).

But herein comes another problem; an object that has mass and is moving at the speed of light is purely speculative... our particle accelerators have yet to accelerate something to those speeds, but doggone close at 0.99997%.  If some form of transport COULD go these rates of motion, it would likely maintain its own inertial space (warp bubble?).  In such a case, light would still obey the same principals as before; as it accelerates away/towards a relative to observer, light frequency would shift it red/violet.

Think of it this way:  speed of light is constrained by the rate by which an electromagnetic field can propagate through so-called space-time.  This limit is given to massless objects in motion.  The speed of light is the result of this wave-particle propagation.  The frequency by which it oscillates is set by its energetic source - and LIKE the doppler effect, can appear stretched or compressed depending on the emitter’s and collector’s relative motion.  Where this differs from the doppler effect is that when the “ball” is released, it maintains no mass, so by constraint, maintains a propagation rate of an EM field in a vacuum.  Thus, if an object is moving through space at the speed of light or faster,  the light emitted from its hull would still travel in the emitted direction at the speed of light, but its frequency would be highly stretched into a very deep redshift, a very low EM frequency.

Ok - not even a GCSE in physics here, so feel free to shoot me down as long as you're willing to explain your thoughts so I can learn something new!  That said, surely the most logical explanation takes into account the ongoing expansion of the universe?  If the "centre" of the universe is the point at which all things are expanding away from, and these objects are moving away from the centre, they can still appear to be exceeding the speed of light if we are also travelling in an opposing direction.  The total perceived velocity of each object from Earth will be the sum of our speed away from the centre of the universe, and the speed of the object in question.  You would also need to adjust for any deviation from absolute divergence.  Even more interestingly, the actual speed of an object may be limited, but there is no limit to the speed at which the universe expands.  In truth, the speed at which we're orbiting the sun, or the speed of the object we're looking at is nothing compared to the rate that the universe is expanding - so the idea that these objects can be best explained as LGMs warping around folding space looking for underpants is almost as funny as astrophysicist Katie Mack who said, "The Universe is expanding the way your mind is expanding. It's not expanding into anything; you're just getting less dense." ...Legend.

The distance between two far away galaxies increases with a rythm that implies that these galaxies are moving away from each other faster than the speed of light. That is correct. The General Theory of Relativity implies that any object with mass cannot move faster than light. That is a theory that helps us explain many, but not all physical phenomena. This should be embarrassing for the Science Channel. It's total garbage. It's actually space that's expanding not galaxies moving through space (although they do move). In other words, galaxies aren't moving through space faster than light, it's space itself that's expanding. So as you look further back in time (further away), it will get to the point that space has expanded so much since light left the object, that light hasn't had enough time to reach us - therefore it's moved beyond our visible horizon. The object essentially red shifts more and more as you go back further in time (i.e. look further away) to the point that it fades and is no longer visible. The laws of physics have not been broken - galaxies are not moving faster than light.

They're not moving faster than the speed of light. They just appear to be because the space between us is expanding. Every light year of intergalactic space between us is independently stretched, so every light year of expanding space between us seems to add to the object's relative velocity. Beyond a certain point, that makes it appear as if distant galaxies are moving away from us faster than the speed of light. But the fact that we're still observing the beam of photons they emit proves that they're not actually traveling away from us faster than light. If they were, we wouldn't be observing them in the first place. Their light would never catch up to us.

The way we account for that is by reasoning that the distance the object's light actually traveled to reach us is shorter than the distance we observe. If that were the case we'd expect to see the wavelength of its light stretched by the expansion of the space it was traveling through. Basically, the wavelengths of light it emits should be longer than the wavelengths we observe from nearby galaxies. And that's exactly what we see. The wavelengths of light emitted by distant galaxies are all shifted to the red end of the spectrum. The end of the spectrum with longer wavelengths.

It's not actually moving faster than light, and the fact that we can still observe its light proves that its light didn't actually travel the full distance we observe. If it were actually moving away from us faster than light, we wouldn't be able to observe the object at all. The stream of photons emitted by the object would never have made it to us. The only way to account for the fact that we are still observing the light those objects emit is to assume that when the beam of light from that distant object left on it's way to us, the distance between us was shorter, and the light w
Every light year of space between us is expanding independently, so the further away an object is, the faster it appears to be moving away from us. Beyond a certain point, the distance between two objects on opposite ends of the observable universe starts to appear greater than the distance light could have traveled in the time it would take the light to get from point a to point b. But the light itself isn't actually traveling that entire distance. It left on its journey to us billions of years ago, when the distance between us wasn't so great. And as it traveled through intergalactic space, the beam of light itself was also stretched by the space it was traveling through.

I'm not any kind of scientist, just an ordinary person... but to me it seems the speed of light is not set and it's false to say nothing can travel faster than light.

Here's why I make that assertion...

If a gun is stationary and fires a bullet at a velocity of 2500fps then the bullet is traveling at 2500fps as relative to the earth. If that same gun is on a plane traveling at 1000fps and fires a bullet forward in the direction of travel at a velocity of 2500fps then the bullet is traveling at 3500fps as relative to the earth. If the gun were to fire the bullet at a velocity of 2500fps rearward to the direction of travel then it would be traveling at a velocity of 1500fps as relative to the earth.

On a galactic scale, say you have a really really big spool of string stretched between two planets, each in separate galaxies with each moving at near the perceived speed of light in directions opposite each other. The light from the one galaxy can never reach the other galaxy because the galaxies are moving away from each other at greater than what we perceive to be the speed of light. But yet the string stretched between planets in each of those galaxies is being spooled out at a rate near twice what we perceive to be the speed of light. Does the string then become unable to be seen by an observer on that planet because it's being spooled out at near twice the speed of light? Would the string cease to exist because to exist it must be spooling out at near twice the perceived speed of light? If the string doesn't cease to exist then it's not accurate to say nothing can travel faster than light.

At the even horizon of a black hole, it's currently perceived that there is a point where light escapes and then a point when light doesn't escape because of intense gravity. What about light near the event horizon, but yet not so near it cannot escape at reduced velocity, it just barely escapes? Photons escaping from being near the event horizon at say 5000fps? Once getting further away from the event horizon, escaping it's influence, do those photons then accelerate themselves up to 186,000mps? If so where do they get the energy to accelerate from 5000fps to 186,000mps? Or do these photons remain at a velocity of 5000fps? What about light traveling towards the event horizon? Wouldn't it then accelerate by magnitudes as it gets closer to the event horizon?

The reason they appear to be going away from us faster than the speed of light is because, they are traveling in one direction at a fraction of the speed of light, while we are traveling in the opposite direction at a fraction of the speed of light. If you didn’t follow that, observe: You are driving west at 60mph. I am driving East at 60mph. You look in your rear view mirror and I appear to be traveling at 120mph, not 60mph, relative to your position.

The definition of "law" from the American Heritage Student Science Dictionary:

"A statement that describes what will happen in all cases under a specified set of conditions. Laws describe an invariable relationship among phenomena."

So it is a "law" that light speed is the fastest velocity, yet in nuclear reactors we see such things as Cherenkov Radiation, which occurs when a charged particle travels through medium faster than light would. (I know, space is not typically looked at as a "medium" and another commenter correctly pointed out that space is nothing more than distance.)

So we know, then, that there are conditions where speeds exceeding light are possible.

It seems that the flaw in the "law" is really our incomplete knowledge of the universe. The law works within the confines of our own technology and mathematics.

Math...math is simply a way to describe physical principles and actions and a tool that can be used to predict new ones. So our understanding is further limited there as well.

Polaris (aka the 'North Star'), for example, is approx. 323 LY away from us, meaning that the light we are seeing now from Polaris is actually the light and the position in which it was approx. 323 'Earth' years ago, and yet we are just seeing that light now. So, where would Polaris actually 'physically' be now? If it has changed its position, we won't 'know' until the light reaches us in 323 years time, or more or less, depending on the position it will be from us at the respective time.

If something is travelling faster than the speed of light, you would never be able to see it since the sight of it would never reach your eyes.  Think of it this way: if you held a moving watch up to a mirror, and then zoomed away from the mirror at exactly the speed of light, you would see a still image of the watch in the mirror since the light of the watch moving would not travel fast enough to reach your eyes.  Faster than the speed of light, and you would not see the mirror at all, since the light from it would be too slow to ever reach your eyes.

The general theory of relativity does place a limit on the speed of objects moving through space. However, when making observations of distant objects you have to take into account the expansion of the universe. Now that we know that the universe has a rest frame which we call the CMB rest frame then by using the velocity of the Milky Way relative to this rest frame we can identify a CMB rest point (using Hubble's law) which is around 26 million light years away from the Milky Way.


Then we can adopt a model in which all galaxies are moving away from the CMB rest point at a velocity which depends on the distance from the CMB rest point and is due to the expansion of space at a rate of 1/(14 billion) light years per year per light year (around 69.84 km/s per Mpc). Now we can adapt the GR rules to say that no object can travel at faster than the speed of light relative to the expanding CMB rest frame. From our point of observation, the velocity of each galaxy can be deconstructed into two components, the velocity due to the expansion of the CMB rest frame and the velocity of the galaxy through the CMB rest frame due to gravitational effects.


https://www.academia.edu/5009126/The_evolution_of_the_universe

I think that this, from John Biretta of the Space Telescope Science Institute, Baltimore, explains things a little clearer:
 "The term `superluminal motion' is something of a misnomer. While it accurately describes the speeds measured, scientists still believe the actual speed falls just below the speed of light.``It's an illusion created by the finite speed of light and rapid motion," Biretta said. ``Our present understanding is that this `superluminal motion' occurs when these clouds move towards Earth at speeds very close to that of light, in this case, more than 98 percent of the speed of light. At these speeds the clouds nearly keep pace with the light they emit as they move towards Earth, so when the light finally reaches us, the motion appears much more rapid than the speed of light. Since the moving clouds travel slightly slower than the speed of light, they do not actually violate Einstein's theory of relativity which sets light as the speed limit."

The speed of light is not constant. It varies depending on the density of the space it is moving through. Space has some density, which is variable. The space fabric close to large bodies like stars is very thin, minimally dense due to the presence of so much matter, which "heats" (radiation-wise) the space fabric around it, thinning it out and reducing its density. Conversely, areas of space which do not have stars are "cooler" (radiation-wise), and the fabric of space is more dense in those regions. Light travelling through pockets of less dense space will travel faster, while light travelling through pockets of denser space will move more slowly. The speed of light is variable. Thus, we cannot trust current readings of red-shift. Stars producing red-shift may not necessarily be moving away from us at high speed. It may be that their light is travelling through a denser pocket of space between us, much like sunlight at sunrise and sunset appears reddish due to passing through a thicker slice of the atmosphere along the horizon. Holding the impossibility of faster than light speed travel in abeyance for just a moment for the purpose of exploring this question, our ability detect objects in space comes from a detection of the electromagnetic vibrations from reflection off of an object, or transmission of electromagnetic vibrations from an object.

If the object is stationary in relation to us, the radiation comes toward us at the speed of light. If it moves away from us, the radiation would still come toward us at the speed of light, but the wavelength generated by the movement causes a relationship. But if the universe itself expands faster than the speed of light, how can electromagnetic energy cross the distance those items moving away from us in that part of the universe, to ever reach us?

There's no conflict. A proper understanding of dark energy will resolve this immediately. Most of the universe is moving away from us faster than the speed of light. Specifically, everything beyond the cosmic horizon, which defines our observable universe. For all things beyond that horizon, there is a sufficient quantity of space between us and them that that space is expanding faster than light can traverse it. Light leaves those objects and races toward us, but as it does so, the distance remaining at each moment never decreases. It goes up and up. Space itself is expanding faster across that total span than any information can ever cover it - so, from our vantage point, the distance between us and those objects increases faster than the speed of light. This is different though from any object traversing space faster than light can traverse space. That is the law that can't be broken. This is about space expanding faster than light can overtake it, which is perfectly legal.

We still can't make our minds up about what is what in our own solar system. We are just now starting to discover things on planets and moons in our home system that we didn't know were possible. The technologies we use to explore space and time are completely inadequate to extrapolate any definitive information outside of our own solar system. We don't know for certain how light and matter react to the gravitational field(s) of our solar system from outside to in, we also don't know how light and matter react and interact within other solar systems within our galaxy in relation to our own. We might think we do, but that fact is that until we can get out there to conduct experiments and research at the outer edge of our solar system, in person, we cannot know anything for certain. We do not know what our asteroid belt surrounding our system contains in its entirety or what unknown elements might exist out there, or what the effects of those unknown elements might be on RF, EM or even light waves throughout the spectrum.

There are several misconceptions about light speed in these comments , which reflects the education system and the lack
of knowledge of the teachers in the education system.
1) light is emitted in all directions at 186,282 miles per second by a light source ( star , flashlight , etc )
so if an object is traveling toward you at 186,282 miles per second then the light emitted from that object no matter
what the speed of the object is , will be emitted away from the object in all directions at 186,282 miles per second.
in essence the light that is emitted away from an object traveling at or above the speed of light is no different than the
light that is emitted away from a flashlight that you hold in your hand.
so the light that is emitted away from a star traveling at light speed will be traveling at 2 x the speed of light
in the direction of travel.

2) if that object were traveling towards you you would not be able to see its light because our eyes cannot see
waves of light that are that short. mind you there is no difference between the light waves emitted from that star
and a flashlight you hold in your hand but the frequency of the waves as they reach your eyes would be too short
for your eyes to distinguish them as visible light waves.

if you were traveling in front of that star at 1 x light speed then you would be able to see the light that the star emits.

I believe in the Atrophy of Photons. Everything in the universe is subject to the law of Atrophy, or the loss of energy over time. As a photon travels through space, it to is subject to this atrophy, or loss of energy. The photon starts off at a high frequency and slowly transitions to a lower frequency, or a shift to the red. Therefore, the farther away an object is the more any light coming from it experiences this red shift. Even if it is relatively stationary to the receiving object, it would appear to be moving away. If that distance is far enough, it could even appear to be moving away at a speed faster than light, if using the Doppler logic.

If our galaxy and the one observed are moving away from each other and both are traveling at or near the speed of light, then it would appear that the observed galaxy is traveling faster than light, but only if you approach it thinking we are stationary in space.

Also you aren't seeing the physical galaxy, rather you see light photons created by that galaxy traveling back towards us, so the idea you wouldn't be able to see it if it was traveling away from us faster than light assumes you don't understand what you see is light photons not the object itself. The suns in the galaxy produce the photons you see it isn't other light sources trying to catch up to the galaxy and then reflecting off the galaxy back towards us that you see.

Now if the galaxy was traveling towards you, then it would exceed the speed of any produced or reflected photons, So then you'd just see dark space.

Einstein may have proved that massless objects (i.e., objects with weight but no mass) could travel faster than the speed of light. This is particularly true if the mass of an object diminishes as it approaches the speed of light or even more abstract if the mass is less than 0. We all know that E=mc**2. If we approach the speed of light, it would seem that it takes more and more energy to accelerate an object, because we know that the weight of a thing does not vary. But is there any reason to believe that weight and mass have a consistent relationship? Weight is defined by the gravitational effect on an object. Mass is not.  If the mass decreases the faster it goes, mass eventually is zero (or perhaps less than zero under certain conditions). So if the mass is zero, then we have E=0*c**2 or in essence, it may take less and less energy to accelerate the object. Other equations from Einstein and others provide more details on this subject and support this conjecture. Experimental results may also support this. If we can see objects moving faster than the speed of light using the Hubble, then there must be some explanation for this. Scientists who claim that the speed of light is a limiting factor are correct if an object has mass (or even worse has more mass if it is accelerating near the speed of light), but since we can observe objects in space moving faster than the speed of light and we have done so for 0ver 50 years now, there must be some reason that these observations are valid.

Halton Arp did extensive research on red shift for most of his career. Being Edwin Hubble's apprentice he was there at the "birth"of the possibility that red shift could a be measure for speed (In contradiction to common belief, Hubble himself doubted very much his own idea and reasoned that there could be other explanations for his measurments).

However after years and years of collecting data and observing thousands and thousands of galaxies using the biggest most powerful telescopes then available he discovered that many galaxies were connected physically to what we know as Quasars. (Halton Arp's finding were bundled in the "Atlas of peculier galaxies", which became a standard work in the world of astronomy) The problem being that quasars were believed to be among the most distant objects in the universe according to there measure of red shift.

How could it be then that they were associated with nearby galaxies with much lower redshifts. Arp came to the conclusions that red shift is mainly a measure of age rather than distance. Most quasars are found in pairs or mutliples roughly positioned within a certain amount of degrees along the rotational axes of their parent galaxies. Arp presented the idea that quasars were objects that were expelled from the center of galaxies with extremely high energy levels (=high redshift) but low mass, in time they would gain mass but decrease in redshift by quantized steps (see any chart with values of redshift quasars and you'll notice these values easily). After a certain amount of time the objects would arc back in their trajectory towards the parent galaxy and become satellite galaxies like our Magellan clouds today are.

The theory is being developed further by scientists that consider a (more or less) revolutionairy concept, that of the the universe being dominated by electromagnetism rather than gravity.
From around Hubble's time (a few decades earlier actually) the concept of an expanding universe created in a "first event", known as the big bang has dominated the field of astronomy. Here too we get in trouble by using red shift as a measure of speed to explain expansion. Because the redshift values observed do no match those calculated for a gradually expanding universe, an early inflationary stage was ad hoc presented as scientific solid, leading to the next problem of expansion rates not matching the observations again leading to another ad hoc solution: "dark energy", allthough there is no means of ever experimentally verifying the concept, WHICH IS WHAT EMPERICAL SCIENCE IS FOUNDED ON.

If however a universe is viewed through the eyes of electromagnetically driven processes there is no need for a "miraculous"(George Lemaitre), or divine big bang (or as Rupert Sheldon likes to echo Terence McKenna : "give us one free miracle and we'll do the rest"). If red shift is a measure of age then the universe could very well be without beginning or end that we can know. Problems with rotational periods of galaxies' most distant stars also follow from the assumption that only gravity plays the game. If electromagnetism is introduced then there is no need for the theoretical concepts (there are many versions) of dark matter allthough the public is led to believe that this is all established science.

Space is expanding at a certain speed, yes. But the speed of light (or more properly, the "speed of causality") only applies to objects moving THROUGH space, not space itself. Space can expand is fast as it damn well pleases, carrying with it the matter that it contains. So the further something is, the faster it's moving away from us because there is more space that is expanding between us.
IF (and that's a big "if") these observations are accurate, the explanation is simple: they're far away, so they're moving away faster simply because the universe is expanding. Given that there is no limit of the speed at which space can expand, it's perfectly plausible to say that that region of space that contains these galaxies is moving faster than the speed of light.
That concept is the only reason that warp drives, something explicitly brought up in the video, could possibly exist.

In 1905 Einstein postulated in his Theory of Special Relativity that the speed of light in free space has the same value in all inertial reference frames. By 1915 with his General Theory of Relativity Einstein had abandoned the postulate that the speed of light in free space has the same value in all inertial reference frames, since speed was in the new theory relative to a gravitational frame of reference. Thus, as Einstein pointed out later in his book "Relativity: The Special and General Theory" we must give up the notion of the speed of light as an absolute speed limit. Why most physicists still do not understand this over 100 years after Einstein so clearly articulated this puzzles me. Let me try to explain with a simple analogy how the speed of objects relative to each other may exceed the speed of light.

No analogy is perfect, or else it would not be an analogy, but let us imagine for a moment that we postulate a law that objects can travel no faster than 600 miles per hour through water (there is no such law, it’s just for explanatory purposes). Now imagine a vast body of water like an ocean. We know that different parts of the ocean can be moving relative to each other, the Gulf Stream current is one example. Now imagine that there are two objects in the ocean traveling at the maximum velocity (which we are imagining is 600 miles per hour) through the water. Let's also say that speed of the Gulf Stream is 5 miles per hour. Let us imagine that two objects are traveling away from each other and one of these objects is traveling along with the Gulf Stream, and the other object is traveling parallel to the Gulf Stream, but not in it, and it is traveling in the opposite direction of the first object. Now both objects are traveling relative to the water around them at 600 miles per hour (the maximum velocity we postulated) but they are traveling relative to each other at the 1205 miles per hour (the speed of each on plus the speed of the Gulf Stream, 5 miles per hour.) Of course, this analogy is not perfect, but it illustrates the principle that since the speed of light is relative to gravitational fields (like the speed of objects in our analogy is relative to the water) and gravitational fields can move relative to each other, the speed of objects relative to each other can and does exceed the speed of light. This fact is especially apparent in objects that are many, many, many gravitational fields away from us, such as very distant galaxies that appear to be moving away from us at speeds much higher than the speed of light, because they are in fact moving away from us at speeds much higher that the speed of light.

Here's an easy answer. The big bang was between us and these galaxies. So, we're heading in one direction, and they're heading in another. You combine the speeds and you get an apparent illusion that they are moving faster than the speed of light. It's just an illusion based on observation. Here's an even simpler way to create the illusion of moving faster than the speed of light. Two moons above the earth. Between them, more than 186 thousand miles. Also, between them is a strip five feet high facing the earth connecting them.You aim a beam of light at one end of the strip at one moon from here on earth, then you twist your wrist and flip the light faster than a second to the other moon. The illusion you get is this light traveling faster than the speed of light. But it's just an illusion.

the answer is actually quite simple. the speed of light is not exempt of the universal decay. in other words the speed of light is actually slowing down. the speed of light was first estimated a thousand years ago during a solar eclipse, and these measurements were thought to be slightly inaccurate - just a tad too fast. fast forward 300 years- same thing, only slighly more accurate. fast forward again to the 1890's - same methods used , and same thing, only even more accurate then previous measurements and impressively a closer measurement. now, they have proven the speed of light is actually slowing over time. at a pretty steady rate. and taking into consideration the previous measurements - calculations state that those measurements that date 10 centuries back, were in fact correct. So, that would mean that if you look back a million years after the big bang, the speed of light would be MUCH MUCH faster than it is now. and the initial blast would in fact send matter out in all directions just under the speed of light - for that time anyway, which is faster than lights top speed now of course. if that werent the case you wouldnt have objects 50 billion light years from eachother when just 13.8 billion years ago they were the same singularity. so natuarally, the further back in time we look the faster things are moving. and they would appear that they are moving faster than the speed of light - but they arent. theyre moving the "ancient speed limit" of light so to speak. If someone 50 billion light years away from us were to watch us (it will take 50 billion years for our light to reach them) we would appear to be moving faster than the speed of light too. because 50 billion years from now the speed of light will be slower

Theres simply no manner in which you can contort a gridded, continuous 3 dimensional medium which allows an object at one grid point to move to another grid point without traversing a continuous set of points between, without tearing the medium all the way around the craft, and when you're talking about putting a spherical tear in spacetime, you're talking about the event horizon of a black hole that you just opened with your ship in the center, bravo. So you can probably put Alcubierre FLT out of mind. It may however, facilitate travel at extremely close to light speed by allowing empty space to essentially be pumped to clear any non photon obstacles from a crafts path. The question is not whether there are things out there that can travel faster than the speed of light. I'm sure there are civilizations even in our galaxy that have cracked that particular nut and have technology that CAN travel faster than light. What I find amusing is someone saying that Hubble has spotted objects traveling that fast. When something travels faster than the speed of light there is no way in hell we would ever see it. Light from the object would be traveling away from us faster than the light from the object would be traveling towards us. Even common sense should tell most people that an object traveling away from us faster than the speed of light could never be seen by us. But let's turn it around. What would happen if an object were traveling towards us faster than light? Would there be an additive effect or would it be like the sonic boom left behind a plane traveling faster than the speed of sound? Interesting question. Galaxies have a red shift or a blue shift depending upon whether they're traveling away from us or towards us. But galaxies are traveling close to the speed of light not faster than.

And how exactly is Hubble supposed to have recorded any light whatsoever from an object moving away at above light speed?

As one approaches the speed of light, your spaceship becomes more and more two dimensional. Your energy requirements rise exponentially until your spacecraft uses up more energy than contained in the entire universe. We're not done yet. You haven't broken the speed of light. Now, time has almost stopped. In order to go the speed of light time stands still and in order to break light speed, you need an infinite amount of energy. Time goes backward, and you can meet your former self trying to break the light barrier. In short, you have broken the laws of physics and you have to eliminate the concept of time altogether, which is pure fantasy. We are, an always will be constrained by the laws of physics, thermodynamics, etc. No amount of technology, know-how, or what have you allows you to short circuit them. This subject is so complex that it would deserve a semester of thought. But in a nutshell, relative to faster than lightspeed objects, the things to look for are: are we seeing such objects moving directly away from us as single images? Are we seeing objects moving in oblique trajectories as dual positioned objects? Are we seeing any objects moving directly toward or at us, long after the object has passed? I am skeptical of any of those ideas, until I see evidence otherwise.
The reason for the speed limit is specifically relative to the detection of objects by light waves. The objects cannot move faster than their images as a stipulation of information theory. However, information theory breaks down relative to entanglement and potentially other quantum magic. However, these may be reasonably assumed not to involve the higher dimensions of electro-magnetics. Light is known by its potential to fire neurons in the photo receptors of the eye. That does not mean that it is the result of photons or the transmission of energy from the object to the eye. In fact spooky worlds could exist independently or in parallel. Spooky worlds are also known to exist on multiple levels - at the level of physics experiments, and in human experience.

Einstein's (actually Lorentz's) law of relative motion DOES NOT forbid an object to move faster than light.  It prevents RELATIVE motions faster than light.  This is one reason the observable universe is limited : because of expansion, the further away galaxies are, the faster they move away from us.  When that RELATIVE speed becomes faster than light, they become un-observable and we don't see them anymore.  It doesn't mean they don't exist anymore, nor that they don't move faster than light IN REGARD TO US, it simply means we can't see nor communicate with them anymore.

Where people in the past have thought things were moving faster than light speed, it turned out to be gravitational red shift added to recessional red shift.

Photons red shift when coming out of a gravity well, especially near a black hole. And that red shift looks the same as a red shift from objects moving very fast away from us.

I noticed some gravitationally lensed objects in the photos where gravity acts like a convex lens and makes things behind such very massive object larger, so such a distortion could create an impression of fast movement, as well as the super-massive black hole causing the lensing.

Now as to warp drive, which exists only in science fiction like the Star Trek franchise, galaxies are LARGE as in getting on a billion, billion miles in diameter, so how big are these imaginary space craft?

Another point, which I don't think matters here is that if we are moving away from an object at 60% light speed, and it is moving away from us at 60% light speed, then it would appear to be moving away from us at 1.2 times light speed.

If there are objects that are traveling faster than the speed of light, you would see patterns in the images we receive.  The light coming from these objects is traveling at the speed of light.   So the ray of light that was closest to the earth will reach earth first, even if it was NOT the first ray of light emitted by the object.   From that time on, there would appear to be two identical objects traveling in opposite directions on the same trajectory.   These are reflections of the same object going forwards and backwards in time over the trajectory of the object.  It would be obvious that these pairings existed in the spread of the objects in the image taken.   The pattern is not there, so the objects are not traveling faster than the speed of light.

How did they conclude that they galaxies were moving away at faster than the speed of light? These objects were being observed using light telescopes. The light from an object moving away from us shifts to longer wavelengths - red shifting is the name. At the claimed speed, if any photons are emitted in our direction, the red shift will become black shift - the wavelength of the received light will be 'infinit' i.e Hubble Telescope can not detect it, we cannot see it, radios cannot sense it - nothing!  In all the excitement, the scientists forgot to tell us what they measured and how they reached this conclusion. Right now to me it looks like a giant mistake or a hoax in the name of science.

This clip appears to rely on some folks I've never seen in the credible scientific community and one I have seen. Seth Shostak is well known as a SETI researcher who I have seen in the credible documentaries like ones on Discovery channel. His comments appear to be clips from other shows where he's talking about SETI. In that case his clips here appear to be taken out of context in order to support the narrative of this show. Here he never says there were any observations of anything moving faster than light. I don't consider this clip to have anything more than speculation to support it. One of the commentators titles was "Technology theorist". How vague is that? Having said all of the above, it is possible in my mind, to have something that may go faster than light. An undiscovered particle for example. In 1979, it was claimed a particle called a tachyon could move faster than light. However, the research hasn't lead to anything substantial I'm aware of except for the 2011 CERN announcement they may have detected a Tau neutrino going faster than light. This was later found to be a timing problem in the fiber optics. Detecting something travelling faster than light with the Hubble would require an extraordinary amount of luck. In any case, who knows what discoveries may await us in the future. To say it would be impossible for anything to go faster than light is to say we've learned all there is to learn about physics.

Anything that artificially lowers the frequencies of those photons can give a calculated recession velocity that is higher than it should be and even higher than that of light in a vacuum.  I suspect that, as those photons traveled through the immense stretches of intergalactic space for billions of years on their way to Earth, they probably lost some of their original energy.  Space is not a perfect vacuum and, in intergalactic space, the concentration of monatomic hydrogen or single hydrogen atoms is about one atom per cubic meter.  That means, as a photon streaks through billions of light years of intergalactic space, it will encounter many hydrogen atoms along the way.  These encounters each extract a tiny amount of energy from a photon and cause its frequency to decrease a bit.  This phenomenon, unfortunately, is still not be properly treated in modern astrophysics, but, once it is, it will become apparent that there are no galaxies receding from Earth in excess of the velocity of light.

Given that speed is all relative in space, since there is no singular point of reference that is guaranteed to not be moving, what exactly IS motion?  If I accelerate to near the speed of light could I not just be slowing myself down to near zero motion while it is actually everything else that is continuing to move at near the speed of light away from me?

And what if two objects move away from each other at half the speed of light each.  Would not each of those objects measure the other one to be travelling at the speed of light?  One object would not be able to determine that it is in fact "moving", except when in reference to another object.  So, if only two objects existed in all of space, what reference is there to say what the speed of one is except for the other object? All each object would see is the distance between them increasing at the speed of light. Now what if they move at 3/4 the speed of light, each? The distance would increase at 1.5 times the speed of light.

But without a stable reference point, how would they be able to determine actual speed?

If a space craft moves away from the earth at 10,000MPH there is a point of reference: The Earth. But say a person who was asleep when you launched from earth woke up and looked out of the window. They might think the Earth is gaining speed while they stay stationary. Or perhaps the space ship is actually slowing down while the Earth continues to move. Much like a car in one lane coming to a stop while the car in the lane next to it keeps going. You haven't actually increased speed, you've merely slowed yourself down relative to something else that hasn't changed velocity at all.

If something is traveling faster than the speed of light, would the light it is emitting then not travel towards us, but also away from us?  Imagine spraying a water hose at someone.  You are both standing still.  The water exits the hose at, lets say 5 mph and travels towards your target.  If your target remained still, but you are now on a vehicle traveling away from the target at the same speed the water is exiting the hose, would not the water just hang in the air and not travel towards the target from the perspective of the target?  If the vehicle was traveling away from the target at a speed greater than the exiting water, then the water, relative to the target, would also appear to be moving away from the target at the difference between the speeds.  Vehicle away at 7 mph, water towards target from vehicle at 5 mph.  Water would be moving away from target at 2mph.  So how can we see anything that was hypothetically moving away from us faster than the speed of light?  The photons required for us to see it would never reach us.

As it turned out, it was a parallax mis-measurement. The galaxies observed were actually headed away from us at a steep angle instead of directly away as the researchers originally thought.
